I hope it shows that whatever they think of us, we‚Äôre cool, we‚Äôre good ‚Äì we just saved your life.‚Äù Now they are determined to use their moment in the spotlight to put politicians under pressure to enact real change.

The Black Lives Matter movement represents "hundreds, thousands of years" of "real pain", Stormzy has said.

On #WorldRefugeeDay, we‚Äôre promising to stand with those seeking safety and sharing the stories of those with #refugee backgrounds in Labour. This is the story of one of Labour‚Äôs most respected figures, Alf Dubs, a tireless campaigner for refugee rights. .
When the Nazis occupied Prague in March 1939, my Jewish father left immediately. My mother was initially refused permission to leave and in July she got me on a Kindertransport. These were arranged by the wonderful Nicky Winton who got 669 children out of Prague to the UK.
.
When the Nazis arrived I remember having to tear a picture of President Benes from my school book and stick in a picture of Hitler. There were German soldiers all over Prague. I remember the scene at Prague station, German soldiers with swastikas watching as parents said a tearful goodbye to their children. At the age of six I was and one of the youngest. Two days later after a long journey across Germany and Holland I arrived at Liverpool Street. I spoke Czech and German and had to learn English fast. I was met by my father so was very lucky. My mother escaped at the last minute but then had to cope after my father died a few months later.
.
By the time of the 1945 election I was passionately interested in politics and knew the names of all the Labour candidates where we were living in Manchester. My mum had taken me to Blackpool for a week and I was sent to hear the early results broadcast by the BBC from the town square. I got back and proudly announced something like "Labour 140, Conservative 30.

Fast forward to 1979 when I was elected for Battersea South. A few years later I was made Shadow Minister for Immigration, Refugees and Race relations I lost in 1987, became CEO of the Refugee Council and joined the Lords in 1994.
.
All along I have been committed to campaigning for refugees. In 2016 I campaigned for the UK to take unaccompanied child refugees from Europe. The Tory Government fought against this but eventually gave in because of public opinion. Another battle followed to continue the right to family reunion.
.
We must continue to fight - we owe that to the many vulnerable child refugees that need help. .
#refugeeweek
